Germany:
February 21, 1970
Dear Debby:
I have been travelling so much in
connection with aviation
and conservation activities that my mail has been terribly
neglected -- letters stacked high and unopened
five trips
around the world last year in addition to I don't know how
This is my second
Europe within two weeks.
to you much
sooner.
I don't keep a permanent secretary, and
temporary help is of little value to me
in the kind of life I
I must be in Hawaii (Pan American) the first week of March.
the end of the week, in New York.
Then the Philippines;
Japan;
then Europe again.
I'd like very much to help with
conservation activities on Captiva and sanibel, but I don't see
how I can get to Florida in the near future.
Anyway, I think
to be
effective the first
steps must be taken by local
organization rather than anything I
could do by flying down
there now.
I suggest the following:
Nature Conservancy is
to salt vate conservations leapprently
encountering on Captiva and Sanibel.
The NC has assisted with
literally hundreds of conservation projects all over the country,
and can give far better advice as to procedure than I can.
president is an extraordinarily able man,
certainly
one of the
best in the field.
(Last year, Anne gave a small
owned in Maine
the Nature Conservancy to include with its
Maine-coast-island project.)
suggest
that you write to Mr. Richards,
the NC president,
for advice about procedures on Captiva and
to say that I suggested this if you wish to.
I expect
to see tir. Richards soon after I return to the United States,
also talk to him about it.
I agree fully that it would
be a tragedy to have those wonderful islands spoihed through
excessive development.
Mr. Thomas W. Richards
Nature Conservancy
Washington, D.C.
Thanks a great deal for the invitation to visit.
I would love to see you,
and also to
come to Captiva
wish I could
say we would hop on a plane and come right down; but
that is simply impossible for me at this time.
Best to you always, in which I know Anne joins me,
